com.itko.lisa.test

Interface CustJavaNodeInterface

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public interface CustJavaNodeInterface
extends java.io.Serializable
    This interface defines the contract that custom java classes must implement to be valid for the CustJavaNode to invoke.

    For a complete overview of the CustJavaNode facility, see the Javadoc for the TestNode itself (CustJavaNode).

    See Also:
    CustJavaNode

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.Object executeNodeLogic(TestExec ts, java.util.Map params)

    • Method Detail

      • initialize

        void initialize(TestCase test,
              org.w3c.dom.Element node)
                throws TestDefException
        This method is called during TestCase construction, only once for each CustJavaNode that is executed. Even if the TestNode is executed many times, it is only initialized once right here.

        You generally won't have anything to do here. There is a built-in parameters support for key/value pairs to enable you to quickly get what you need. However, if you have defined a set of custom XML tags that your component requires, this method gives you the opportunity to read those tags during construction of the TestCase.

        Parameters:
        test - the TestCase XML document
        node - the CustJavaNode's Node element w/i the TestCase document.
        Throws:
        TestDefException - throw this if you have a fatal problem with the XML objects you are sent.

      • getParameters

        ParameterList getParameters()
        This important method defines the parameter set that is needed by your custom compoennt. For example, let's say you are testing an LDAP server, so (simplifying) you will need an id, password, servername, and organizational realm. You would construct the ParameterList in this method such that each of those parameters is a key and has a default or empty value.

        This method gives the LISA Test Case Editor the ability to provide a dynamic UI on top of your parameters. It will call this method, then render a form to fill those in.

        When you need the current value of those parameters at runtime, they will be given to you as a Map of the key that was provided here, and the current value from Test Execution state or the hardcoded value. That is to say, parameter values from the Test Case can be fixed values, like "ldapqaserver" or {{ldapsvr}} which will be converted to its current value from the Test Execution state.

        Returns:
        a ParameterList object of the parameters needed by this component

      • executeNodeLogic

        java.lang.Object executeNodeLogic(TestExec ts,
                                java.util.Map params)
                                  throws TestRunException
        This is the biggy. Here you are given the opportunity to execute your logic within the scope of a Test Execution. You perform your specific logic here. In our LDAP example, you would read the Map of parameters for your login/realm data, and execute the logic needed to perform your LDAP login. If you want to access or modify any aspect of the test's execution status, the TestExec object you are given is all you need.

        Parameters:
        ts - the TestExec object that provides you with access to get and modify the state of the currently running test execution. For example, use ts.setNextNode() to tell LISA what TestNode to execute immediately after this Node finishes.
        params - these are the parameters that have been provided by the Test Case author for you to use while executing your test logic. They are in a Map, ie., key/value pairs. The keys come directly from the Test Case XML document, and the values are either the constants provided in the TestCase document or are the values substituted for the keys that were specified in TestCase document. For example "uid={{current.user.id}}" would have a Map entry of "uid=u001".
        Returns:
        An Object that represents the result from the system under test. For web sites, this is usually an HTML document; Web Services return XML documents; others will return Data objects.
        Throws:
        TestRunException - if you cannot execute your custom node logic for some reason and you want to end the test because of this, then throw this exception. Less dramatic ways to notify the test executor of an error are to use the log output and TestEvent facilities that are accessible from the TestExec object.
        See Also:
        CustJavaNode, TestEvent
